direction.raw_text: because it's half-life is fifty-five hundred years, so they must have found have of it gone and figured that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why isn't it wet? Orlean wrote about wading through black, corrosive water. She said it was the scariest experience of her life. And when I spoke to you on the phone, you said wear heavy boots, long pants and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's usually water. We've been going through a bit of a drought. Say, have you seen that movie, Medicine Man? That's a good movie about protecting nature. It shows there could be something important in a rain forest we don't even know about, like a cure for cancer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not even hot. I was expecting it to be awful. Sun beating down, wading through water, looking out for snakes, wild hogs. I was thinking it would be dramatic. Alligators. Something!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The alligators are over by the lakes. The temperature's a blessing for us. This time of year can get uncomfortably hot. (pointing excitedly) Green anole. Florida's most common. Kaufman looks down and sees a plain-looking little lizard hanging on a tree. Mike Owen jots it down in his notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I try to keep a log of sightings. INT. TRUCK - DAY Mike Owen drives.    Kaufman stares out the window at boring trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It had been a hard day and I hadn't seen what I'd come to see. Maybe the ghost orchid was a ghost after all. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are certainly ghosts in the Fakahatchee -- ghosts of rangers who were murdered years ago by illegal plume hunters, and of loggers who were cut to pieces in fights, and for years there has been an apparition wandering the swamp, the Swamp Ape, which is said to be seven feet tall and seven hundred pounds and have the physique of a human, the posture of an ape, and the body odor of a skunk. EXT. RANGER SHACK - DAY Kaufman and Owen stand by Kaufman's car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What Laroche did was wrong. Those flowers belong to all of us, all 250 million of us -- 250? I think it's up to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: now -- And belonging to all of us means they belong to none of us. Nobody has a right to take them. Not me, not you, not John Laroche, not... Kaufman is desperate for something else.    He blurts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, um, Susan Orlean wrote about a legendary creature called a Swamp Ape. Have you ever heard stories or -- MIKE OWEN (pissy) Tourist garbage! I don't know why people need to invent silly creatures to make nature fascinating. Isn't nature amazing enough?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shamed) I just asked because she mentioned it. INT. HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT Orlean, still dirty from the swamp, holds a phone to her ear and talks to us. She has cute little dirt smudges on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That night I called Laroche.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) I didn't see anything but bare roots. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I had this thought. Maybe the ghost orchid only blooms in the minds of people who've walked too long in the swamp. INT. ORLEAN'S APARTMENT - NIGHT Orlean types. It's pouring and sheets of rain beat against her window. She glances at her husband, across the room reading a book. She sighs, continues typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I didn't say to him is that life seemed to be filled with things that were just like the ghost orchid -- wonderful to imagine and easy to fall in love with but a little fantastic and fleeting and out of reach. INT. RENTAL CAR - EVENING Kaufman drives down a Florida strip-malled highway. He passes a Barnes and Noble, a Burger King, a Starbucks. He parks in front of a California Pizza Kitchen. INT. CALIFORNIA PIZZA KITCHEN (FLORIDA) - EVENING Kaufman watches the waitresses. One approaches his booth. Her name badge reads: Caryn, Tampa, FL. She smiles at Kaufman as she looks right through him. INT. HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT A morose Kaufman sits on the bed reading The Orchid Thief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I didn't say to him was that life seemed to be filled with things that were just like the ghost orchid -- wonderful to imagine and easy to fall in love with but a little fantastic and fleeting and out of reach. Kaufman is deeply moved. He hi-lites the passage, then looks at the smiling photo of Orlean. He finds himself lost in it. INT. HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT Orlean, dirty from the swamp, is on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beat,clears throat) Jesus Christ, of course there are ghost orchids out there! I've stolen them! (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beat, a cleared throat) You should have gone with me. CLOSE-UP OF MAGAZINE The line: "... then he cleared his throat and said: 'You should have gone with me.'"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beautifully written. A really unique piece. PULL BACK TO: INT. RESTAURANT - MIDDAY Busy lunch crowd. Valerie sits at a table with Orlean and an open New Yorker magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.      Thanks very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're big fans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Laroche is such a fun character.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, John's a character all right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's funny and fresh.     And sad in a way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, thanks. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we were wondering, what's next?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, um, Random House wants me to expand it into a book. So I'll be doing that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there'll be more of Laroche?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.   More John, more orchids. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know, we'd really like to option it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing) You want to make this into a movie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laroche is such a fun character.   So... INT. VAN - DAY Laroche, wearing a Cleveland Indians T-shirt, drives crazily thorugh the Hollywood Seminole reservation. Orlean holds on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No shit I'm a fun character. (beat) Who's gonna play me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got to write it first. Someone's gotta write the screenplay. Most things never get made. It's premature to -- LAROCHE I think I should play me. Laroche swerves into a parking space in the nursery lot. EXT. SEMINOLE NURSERY   - DAY Laroche and Orlean get out of the van.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got all the right qualities. While you write, I'll take an acting class. A few young Indian guys are hauling bags of potting soil. They look at Laroche sourly. Laroche indicates the giant cartoon Indian on his T-shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wear this just to screw with 'em. INT. TRAILER - CONTINUOUS Laroche enters his office, looks at some papers on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most of them don't even bother calling me John anymore. It's "Crazy White Man" now. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Crazy White Man" is a good title for the movie. Call the book "Crazy White Man." Or, I don't know, "Collector of Hearts" or something. Before Orlean can respond, Laroche picks up the phone and dials an impossibly long number. He waits, gestures for Orlean to sit on a chair piled high with junk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't hurt anything. Orlean moves the junk over, shares the seat with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Yelling into phone) Hello? Hello? Hi? This is John Laroche from the Seminole Nursery. Sem-ih-nole! (to Orlean) How do you say Seminole in Spanish? (into phone) That's right, yes! Yeah, I want to order some more of those pink string beans! Pink string beans! (yelling) Pink String Beans! Pink String Beans! Buster appears in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) I'll call back. (hangs up) Hey, Buster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was trying to order some pink string beans from Argentina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No kidding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I figure just because Project Ghost Orchid is dead, we're not closing shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, John -- (CONTINUED) 59. CONTINUED: (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll get into plant multiplication. Buy little ones, turn 'em into big ones, sell 'em at a profit. Simple plant multiplication for the masses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John, we're thinking maybe now's a good time for you to take a few weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't need a vacation, Buster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a good time.   Things are slow. Laroche stares at Buster.   Buster stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know, the guys on my crew here, all they do is smoke weed all day. I been meaning to talk to you about that. So if it's a question of productivity -- INT. VAN - A FEW MINUTES LATER Laroche weaves through traffic.   Orlean holds on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're gonna fire me. Goddamn politics. Crazy White Man's bad publicity. (pounds steering wheel) I can't believe I'm dealing with this! (pounds steering wheel) Like I could give a damn. If they fire me, I'll sue. I already did some legal research on this when I was doing the other shit. They can't fire me. And I ain't going to quit. MONTAGE Gray skies. Kaufman drives his rental car: he looks at the Seminole Nursery, the Collier County Courthouse, Laroche's house. He drives through swampy terrain. He walks around at an orchid show, he attends a slide-show orchid lecture. It's all dull. He ends up sitting on a bench on an empty beach, staring out at the ocean. INT. HOTEL ROOM - DAY Orlean dials the phone.   It rings for a long time.    Finally: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (groggy) Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John, it's Susan. (waits for response) Orlean. (waits) So, I was just wondering if you might be willing to talk some more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about? Orlean rolls her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, John, I'm trying to put together a book. Don't just abandon me down here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm no longer interested in orchids. I'm pursuing other avenues. I apologize for any inconvenience this might cause you. Orlean is silent, taps her fingers on the bedside table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for your time. Laroche hangs up. Orlean sits there for a moment, flips through her list of orchid collector names. EXT. EMPTY BEACH - DAY Kaufman sits on the bench, looking out at the ocean. An attractive, spandexed couple skate by, chatting in German. He watches the woman, hoping for a look, for something. He doesn't get it. They're gone. A tan older man sits on the bench, lights a cigarette. Kaufman continues to look at the ocean, even though he feels the guy's eyes on him. He doesn't want to engage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We could use the rain, huh? Kaufman nods, looking at the ocean.      Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you from around here? Kaufman shakes his head "no."   Pause. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So where then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (excitedly) Yeah? I'm moving to L.A. I just wrote a screenplay. I sent it to a lot of agents. But if they turn me down, I'll go there and market it myself. I used to be in marketing in New York, so I know exactly how to sell this thing. (beat) Where's a nice place to live if you don't have a car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You kind of need a car. I guess West Hollywood would be okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you recommend West Hollywood then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not recommending it. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I moved down here for a change, and I wrote the screenplay. Just like that. It's a great idea. The old guy waits for a response.    He gets none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's about a mob guy, but it's not your regular mob story. There's a twist. A cop tells this mob guy's wife that the mob guy's cheating on her. But the truth is, the cop's lying because he wants her for himself. See, they used to go together in high school. (waits for response, then:) You know anything about screenplays? Kaufman shakes his head. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, the object is to make people think you're going in one direction, then you twist it to keep 'em surprised. I came up with all these amazing twists out of nowhere. Well, not nowhere. (beat) I'm a born again Christian. (beat) You have faith?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.     Not really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't believe in anything? Kaufman shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how you can look out at this beautiful ocean and not believe there's an intelligence that created it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you can't know until you experience it. That requires accepting Jesus Christ as your Lord and Savior. Believe me. Lookit, if I was to show you a bottle of clear liquid and told you it was vodka, how would you know if it really was or if it was water? There's only one way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd smell it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (annoyed) No. You can't smell vodka.    You'd have to taste it, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It could be poison.    I don't know you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angry) Look, let's go with the analogy I'm drawing here. It's not poison. Okay? (resuming control) (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you'd have to taste it to know. Right? That's my point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all I'm saying. (beat) So West Hollywood, huh? I think I'll make it out this year. Because how long can you look at an ocean, y'know? MONTAGE Susan Orlean talks to various orchid enthusiasts, visits nurseries, sits in lecture halls, attends orchid shows, sits in the library reading orchid books. She is bored and distracted. INT. AIRPLANE - NIGHT A stewardess places a cup and an airline-sized bottle of vodka down in front of a lost Kaufman. He smiles at her.    No response. He opens the bottle and smells the vodka. INT. LIMO - NIGHT Kaufman sits in the back seat and stares out the window. The driver looks at him a couple of times in his rearview mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have failed. I have nothing to say.    I am fat. I am not a writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Kaufman, do you mind if I ask what type of work you do for Sony?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (impressed) A song writer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm a screenwriter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, wow! Good for you. You mind if I ask what your movie's about? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's about flowers. No response.   Kaufman tries to make it interesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's about this poacher who steals orchids out of a swamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard about that!   Drug flowers, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.   That's it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard about that! That's great! Action-adventure is my favorite genre. INT. EMPTY HOUSE - NIGHT Kaufman enters with his bags and heads to the stairs. Donald, typing furiously at his desk, looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How was Florida, man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (climbing the stairs) Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cool! Hey, my script's going amazing! Right now I'm working out an Image System. Bob calls it an invaluable asset. Because of my multiple personality theme, I've chosen the motif of broken mirrors to show my protagonist's fragmented self. Bob teaches that an Image System greatly increases the complexity of an aesthetic emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sound like you're in a cult. Kaufman disappears upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's just good writing technique. (types, then:) (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I made you a copy of McKee's Ten Commandments. I've posted one over both our work areas. INT. EMPTY BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Kaufman tears down MCKEE'S TEN COMMANDMENTS. Donald appears backlit in the doorway and seems oddly threatening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shouldn't have done that. They look at each other.    Donald breaks the tension, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Cause it's extremely helpful. (lies down on floor) Hey, any sign of that Swamp Ape?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no Swamp Ape. It was invented for people who can't find the actual world fascinating. Y'know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, okay. I didn't know that. Sorry. Hey, I got a song! "Happy Together." I was worried about putting a song in a thriller, but Bob says, Casablanca, the greatest screenplay ever written, did exactly that. Mixed genres.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to go to bed, Donald.    I haven't slept in a week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Donald remains on the floor. MONTAGE SEQUENCE Mishmash of images: alligators snapping, Laroche jabbering, Orlean typing, 19th century orchid poachers slogging, orchids blooming, Mike Owen lecturing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... so we open the swamp... okay, flashback to young Laroche had turtles... Okay, Susan says What Is Passion? And okay we open on a swamp and suddenly a white van comes tearing around...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. EMPTY BEDROOM - NIGHT Kaufman lies half-awake in bed, sweating, his eyes darting back and forth. He looks over at the clock. It's 3:32.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn it. Donald snores happily off-screen.   Kaufman switches on a lamp, pulls The Orchid Thief from his bag, flips through it. There are now many yellow hi-lited passages. He reads one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are too many ideas and things and people, too many directions to go. I was starting to believe the reason it matters to care passionately about something is that it whittles the world down to a more manageable size.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Such sweet, sad insights.   So true. Kaufman flips to the glowing, smiling author photo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're... I like looking at you. He stares at the photo.   Its smile broadens.    It talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like looking at you, too.   Charlie. The photo smiles warmly at him.   Kaufman begins to jerk-off. He closes his eyes. Then: Kaufman and Orlean are in his bed together, making love. She smiles at him throughout. They finish. Then: Kaufman is alone in bed, heaving. He looks at the still smiling photo. It somehow seems sleepy now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how to do this. I'm afraid I'll disappoint you. You've written a beautiful book. I can't sleep. I'm losing my hair. I'm fat and repulsive -- ORLEAN PHOTO Shhh. You're not. Whittle it down, focus on one thing in the story, find the thing you care passionately about and write about that. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Kaufman studies her delicate, melancholy face.      He's in love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sweet, flirty smile) I figured there might be something... INT. KITCHEN - MORNING Kaufman paces and talks animatedly into his mini-recorder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Susan Orlean, delicate, fragile, beautiful, haunted by loneliness, typing at her desk. She looks at the camera and talks to us: "John Laroche is a tall guy, skinny as a stick, pale-eyed, slouch- shouldered..." Donald enters in his underwear, pours coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, hey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You seem chipper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm good.     I have some new ideas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cool. Me too. I'm putting in a chase sequence now. The killer flees on horseback with the girl. The cop is after them on a motorcycle. It's like a battle between motors and horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're all still one person, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, hey, that's the big pay-off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nice) Well, it sounds exciting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, man. Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. CAR - DAY Orlean drives through swampy landscape.   She talks to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose what I'd been doing in Florida was trying to understand how people found order and contentment and a sense of purpose in the universe by fixing their sighs on one single desire. Now I was also trying to understand how someone could end such intense desire without a trace. Orlean stops at a payphone and dials.   It rings for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (groggy) Yeah what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, John, it's Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, how's everything going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great! I'm training myself on the internet. It's fascinating. I'm doing pornography. It's amazing how much these suckers will pay for photographs of chicks. And it doesn't matter if they're fat or ugly or what.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That sounds good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's great is what it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I've been meeting a lot of orchid people, going to shows, I thought you might want to hear about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. I am officially no longer interested in orchids or the losers who are still interested in them. The end. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Laroche hangs up.   Orlean looks off into the flat distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you really loved something, wouldn't a little of it always linger? She turns to the camera. INT. EMPTY BEDROOM - NIGHT Kaufman holds The Orchid Thief open with one hand and types with the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan Orlean drives. The golden light of the afternoon sun caresses her sweet face. She talks to us. (copying from book) "Florida is a landscape of transition and mutation, a hybrid of ..." Kaufman's hand slips, the book shuts. He opens it to the wrong page and sees an About The Author paragraph. The last line jumps off the page: "She now lives in New York City with her husband." EXT. L.A. STREET - NIGHT Kaufman wanders the street, distraught.   A passing woman snickers. INT. EMPTY BEDROOM - NIGHT Kaufman types.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan and her husband eat dinner in silence. A dying relationship. Husband: You want to do something tonight? Susan: I should work. Y'know. I got stuff... INT. EMPTY LIVING ROOM - DAY Kaufman and Orlean move furniture into the room. It now looks warm and inviting. Orlean wears a bandana kerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so thrilled I get to adapt your book, get to merge my thoughts with yours. I love that. It's intimate, like a marriage. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not like a marriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe what marriage could be. Her eyes tear up.    She kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it ironic? You adapting my book? My three years in Florida meditating on my inability to experience passion resulted in my finding it with you. INT. EMPTY BEDROOM - MORNING Kaufman paces with his mini-recorder.    Off-screen typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and in the final sequence Susan as a young girl swings alone in the backyard. From high in the air she sees her parents in separate rooms staring blankly in opposite directions. This symbolizes the profound scarring their waning passion has had on the girl's psyche, how she became afraid to ever really love something because it would go away. Kaufman is immensely pleased.    He smiles at Orlean's photo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is good. I'm finding you. The phone rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yallo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Charlie. It's Valerie. Just bugging you again. How's everything going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.     I think really good now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great.    So I spoke to Susan yesterday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beat) Oh. Uh-huh, uh-huh. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told her you were making terrific progress and she's really excited to read the script. Sweat appears on Kaufman's brow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.   Good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she said she'd love to meet you. All color drains from Kaufman's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um, well, y'know, for me it's distracting to... or confusing to discuss what I'm exploring in the screenplay at this point... before I finish... it. So...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fair. I'll let her know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Susan I'd be very happy to meet her at a future date. As she sees fit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.   Good enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And tell her how much I love her book. Say I think she's such a great writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want your writing to be original. You want to have an original voice like Neil Simon or Nora Ephron. Well, let me tell you something, my friends. The key to originality is not eccentricity. A guy behind Kaufman gives an appreciative "mmmm."

direction.raw_text: Long speechs are antithetical to the nature of cinema. The Greeks called it stykomythia -- the rapid exchange of ideas. A long speech in a script, say a page long, requires that the camera hold on the actor's face for a minute. Look at the second hand on your watch as it makes one complete rotation around the clock face and you'll get an idea of how intolerable that would be for an audience. The ontology of the screen is that it's always now and it's always action and it's always vivid. Life is rarely vivid. And that's an important point. We are not recreating life on the screen. Writers are not tape recorders. Have you ever eavesdropped on people talking in a coffee shop? Then you know how dull and tedious real conversation is. Real people are not interesting. There's not a person in this world -- and I include myself in this -- who would be interesting enough to take as is and put in a movie as a character.
direction.name: direction

A child watches her mother beaten to death on the steps of a church! Someone goes hungry! Somebody else betrays his best friend for a woman! direction.raw_text: Charlie! Listen, let's talk! This pie is big enough for four people! (to Orlean) Why are there two of him? Orlean shrugs.

direction.raw_text: Identical twigs? (laughs crazily) Did I say twigs? I meant twins. Kaufman and Donald run through a colony of sawgrass. It slices them like razor blades. Kaufman yells in pain. Blood oozes through their shirts and pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cladium jamaicense, guys. Sawgrass. You want to watch out for that. That's some evil shit. Cut you up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you, Laroche!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just tryin' to be helpful. Walk with us and I'll be sure you avoid all the pitfalls. I know these swamps forwards and backwards. There's alligators and poisonous snakes, fellas. Wild hogs. Kaufman and Donald are stopped by a large body of water. Nowhere to go. Laroche and Orlean close in. The brothers run along the periphery of the lake. Donald stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait.   Do you hear something? Kaufman stops, hears a distant galloping and squealing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donald, that sounds bad. The brothers run in the opposite direction. The galloping gets louder. It's wild pigs. Donald spots an airboat on the shore. They jump onto it, search hysterically in the dark for bow to start it.   The pigs get closer. Laroche and Orlean get closer. Donald finds a button, presses it, the engine starts. They pull away from the shore just as the pigs catch up. One pig leaps on board, squealing. Kaufman kicks at it as Donald attempts to steer the boat. A kick connects and the pig flies into the water. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (2) Laroche stands at the shoreline and fires his rifle. It nicks the boat. Donald looks back and the boat heads for a cypress stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch out, watch out, watch out! Donald gets the boat back on course. Laroche and Orlean have been left far behind. Donald slows the boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we're okay. Suddenly Laroche's van comes tearing around a corner and speeds along the road at the water's edge. Orlean shoots at the boat from the van window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on! Donald speeds up. The van keeps up, the shooting continues. Bullets whiz. Kaufman puts his head in his hands. A bullet hits the airboat's gas tank. It explodes in a ball of flame, illuminating the whole swamp. Kaufman and Donald are thrown, along with flaming pieces of debris. Donald treads water, looks all around for Kaufman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles?!    Charles?! Where are you? Underwater. A dazed Kaufman tries to get his bearings. The murky lake bottom is lit a dim orange by the fire on the surface. An alligator appears. Kaufman panics, surfaces. On the surface, Donald spots Kaufman pop out of the water, then get jerked back down. Donald dives. Underwater. The alligator violently shakes Kaufman by the leg. Donald surfaces, comes back down with a broken propeller blade. He hacks the alligator's head off, grabs Kaufman, and brings him to the surface. Donald swims to shore with Kaufman in tow.    Another shot is fired. It skims the water near Kaufman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck!   Fuck, Donald, we're dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're okay. How's your leg?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. How's your back. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's fine.     My back is fine. Laroche and Orlean circle the lake in the van, shooting. Mike Owen, in pajamas, leaves his house, jumps in his truck and agitatedly drives toward the noise and flames. Donald makes it to shore. He climbs out and is helping Kaufman, when he gets hit by a bullet and falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donald! Kaufman sloshes to shore. His right leg is bloody and mangled. He lifts his brother's head onto his lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're gonna be okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  But don't let them get you, too. (weak smile) You got a fucking awesome third act.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crying) Donald, this is an awful, bizarre thing to say and an awful time to say it, but I'm sorry I didn't get to know you better. I'm so sorry. I'm so sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's really... You've been really nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, it's just I thought I knew you already. I thought you were me. And I hated me. Donald touches Kaufman's face. Kaufman looks at his brother. Donald's face glows radiantly in the fire light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, don't do that anymore.      Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Donald dies. Kaufman screams heavenward. The van appears out of the bush, barreling for them. Kaufman rolls his brother out of the way, and limps off into a slough. The van follows, smashes into a tree, and comes to a halt. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (4) Smoke pours from the grill and is lit by the headlights.         Out of the smoke, Laroche and Orlean appear with guns. They follow Kaufman into the swamp. Mike Owen pulls next to the disabled van. He gets out, surveys the mess, sees bloody Donald on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, that writer guy. Owen grabs his C.B., tries to radio for help. It's broken. He lifts Donald into the back of the truck and speeds off. Kaufman limps through the dark water.       Laroche and Orlean follow the sound of his sloshing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Water sounds so sparkly. Like lemon plastic jewels plopping onto a silver trampoline! Dontcha think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darlin', please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we fuck now, baby?    Fuck like lemons? Owen tears along the dirt road. Up ahead, Kaufman limps out of the swamp, into the truck's headlights. Owen is confused. He checks the back to see if Donald's body is still there and skids off the road into the swamp. Kaufman hurriedly limps over to the disabled truck. Owen climbs out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gotta help me.    You gotta help me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is going on here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're after me. They've got guns. They killed my brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's got guns? What are you -- Before Owen finishes, his truck is flipped over. Donald's body flies into the water. There, staring Kaufman and Owen down, is a giant man-like beast. It's repulsive, covered in algae-matted fur.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy shit. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (5) The two men turn and run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's real!     I can't believe it, I never -- The creature grabs Owen and snaps his neck like a toothpick. Kaufman screams as he runs, watches over his shoulder. He runs right into the arms of Orlean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, it's the screenwriter!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a thing back there!    You don't want to be here. Kaufman, Orlean, and Laroche look back. Nothing there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right, I don't want to be here. I'm tired, let's get this over with. Laroche puts the gun to Kaufman's head. Kaufman tenses. Orlean studies Laroche's gun. Her nose is practically touching the barrel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love your gun, baby.    Can we trade?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stand back, sweetness. Laroche reaches for Orlean's arm to pull her away. Suddenly the creature grabs Laroche, pulls him into the swamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susie!   Susie! Orlean looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd Johnny go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susie! Orlean, agitated and disoriented, fires repeatedly into the darkness. Something slumps forward in the water. Orlean steps cautiously over, keeping her gun on Kaufman. The creature is dead, so is Laroche. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (6)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crying softly) Oh, Johnny. She sits next to Laroche and pets his head.   Kaufman watches her. The sun is coming up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd just stare at your picture, and you looked so sweet. I read your words and I thought you were smart and maybe lost and lonely like me. And the way you wrote about Laroche. You said he was handsome even though he had no front teeth -- ORLEAN Oh, Johnny. Johnny's teeth.     Oh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I figured you could look at me and see something, even with all my flaws you could look at me and find something, you could maybe someday write a description of me that would be nicer than the one I write day in and day out in my head. (hopefully) Would it be? Kaufman takes Orlean's chin in his hand and directs her gaze to him. She stares at him for a long while, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're really so wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So wonderful. I can see inside your soul. It glows with orange sadness. It's raining inside you. I want to run through your dripply dripples. It's so beautiful. I love you. I do. Kaufman lets go of her face and sits on a rock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the drugs. Orlean stands and walks toward Kaufman. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: (7)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's me. It's the real me. Look at you. I just want to hold you and -- Oh, crap, it's wearing off. Crap! She paces, unfolds her little square of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm out.     I'm fucking cleaned out. Kaufman watches her for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, bye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't let you go, fatty.    I can't let you make this public. Kaufman keeps walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You hear me? You pathetic, fat, bald... You don't even know how to write! You're not even... You're not leaving here! (screaming, crying) I need a fix! Everything's so ugly! Orlean screams in anguish. Kaufman keeps walking. Orlean shakily aims the gun at his back. She shoots. Kaufman falls, gets up, keeps walking. She aims again through her tears. Suddenly she's pounced on by a bloody, soaking wet figure. Kaufman turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donald! Kaufman limps back.    Donald and Orlean roll on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My brother is not fat. He's not bald. My brother is a great writer! He was trying to do something important! The gun fires. Orlean slumps over Donald. Kaufman arrives. Both Donald and Orlean are dead. Kaufman falls to his knees. EXT. SWAMP - MORNING The sun is high. Fires smoulder. A tow-truck extricates one of the crashed vehicles. State police cars, ambulances, ranger trucks abound. Kaufman is wrapped in a blanket. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: He is with a cop and pointing to the bodies spread on a black plastic tarp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's Mike Owen. John Laroche. Susan Orlean. I don't know what that is. I think it might be a Swamp Ape. And that's Donald, my twin brother. He saved my life. Kaufman cries a little.    The cop waits sympathetically, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You two really look alike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (proudly) Yeah. Yes, we do. INT. CALIFORNIA PIZZA KITCHEN - DAY Kaufman sits in a booth, working longhand on a legal pad. He's a little scraped-up, a little tougher. A copy of Story by McKee is among his reference material. Alice, the waitress, walks by and glances at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I love McKee! (recognizes Kaufman, gets reserved) Oh, hi. Haven't seen you in a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.    Yeah, I've been away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you studying screenwriting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm actually finishing one up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good for you! Me too. God, it's so hard to get in, huh? Everyone and their brother is writing a screenplay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Actually I'm writing this one for Sony Pictures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Wow. Really?   That's so cool. (beat) (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow! So what's it about, if you don't mind my asking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's tough. Let's see... about being yourself, maybe. It's about learning that if you can't love yourself, you can't really love anyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's true. God, that's so true.     It's such an important message, y'know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, my twin brother was murdered recently -- ALICE Oh God!    I'm sorry.   That's so horrible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. Like part of me ripped away. Forever. It was a wake up call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry. You poor man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, it helped put things in perspective. Life is a miracle. All life, from the flower to the human being. You. Me. And I want to show people that. For my brother. For everyone. There's a pause.       Alice just stares at him, in awe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, do you mind if I sit for a sec?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're working.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrugs) It's a stupid job, y'know.    I'm Alice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like that name. Charlie. I've always really liked that name. Charlie. Alice smiles, sits.      The two of them begin to talk.
direction.name: direction
